div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,486] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, MAY 7, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRÆUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suaskin every Wedesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m a steamer leaves Suez for JEDDAH continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODEIDAH, and ADEN. Intermediate streamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice.

*Sleeping and Dining Cars. - During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Cars trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays, and Saturdays at 6:30 p.m, and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1906, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Cars will be attached to the ordinary nigh trains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.

Subscribed Capital £ 1.500,000
Reserve Fund " £ 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 3 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they full due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English Daily Newspaper, Established 1880.
Editor and Manager - - R. SHELLING
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF
MONDAY, MAY 7, 1906
LORD CROMER AND EGYPTIAN COMPANIES

Lord Cromer’s Report covers such a vast field that it is impossible for us to deal with the many subjects of economics, finance, administration, and work of the Ministries in one short article. Each reader will seek for himself the chapter which interests him most, and there are few indeed who have not some interest in one or more of the Egyptian companies. These will read with close attention what Lord Cromer has to say of the economic condition of the country as bearing on companies, present and future. The attitude of the Government towards commercial undertakings is explicitly stated. It is no function of a Government to distinguish between good and bad investments. Of that the investor must himself be the sole judge. There has been too much talk of Egyptian "booms” as if we were all being carried along on a tidal wave of prosperity to find ourselves presently stranded or dashed on the rocks. Clearly and logically Lord Cromer reviews the situation leading to the conclusion, in which he will have the support of those who best know the country, that the prosperity of Egypt is no mushroom growth which will eventuate in a reaction. We heartily welcome such a much-needed authoritative statement of the physician whose finger has been on the pulse of Egypt for a quarter of a century. Whilst this hopeful view will encourage the bona-fide investor it most not be concluded that there is no word of warning for the reckless and over-sanguine. Far from it, for it is clearly pointed out that Egypt is an agricultural country liable to the vicissitudes of crops, markets, and plant diseases, and though in many respects less liable to these than other countries, still, entire exemption may not always be looked for. The masterly exposition of conditions in Egypt must be read in its entirety to be folly appreciated, and we heartily commend a careful perusal of the chapter to all who take an interest in the country. Investors must neither assume that all Egyptian undertakings are based on an unsounded foundation, nor must they ran to the opposite extreme of judging them all as sound concerns. "Caveat emptor” is a sound motto, and no Government can wholly protect a fool. Egypt can absorb much capital, which can be safely and profitably employed in development of land and in other ways, but the company promoter is as unscrupulous as he is ubiquitous and if he mislead the unwary by garbled quotations from Lord Cromer’s Report, the victim has himself alone to blame. Encouragement and warning are so blended that the timorous and unwary will find much for their guidance, and for our part we cannot see what more could have been said for their direction.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Plague.
To-day’s bulletin records a death at Deshna and a fatal case in the Kous district.
Mouled el Nebi.
The feast of the Prophet was celebrated at Cairo as usual with great rejoicings The Khedive presided at the fête.
Luxor Winter Palace.
The internal arrangement of this hotel will be complete on 1st January next, when the hotel will be open to receive tourists.
Alhambra.

The revne which has been running at this theatre for a fortnight has given place to a variety entertainment. This evening there will be a gala performance for the benefit of Mlle Pilar Garcia, the charming Spanish dancer.
The Tabernacle of Israel.

Mr. Jos. C. Dutton will deliver his lectures on the Tabernacle of Israel, illustrated with a large model, for the English soldiers in the Presbyterian chaplain’s meeting room at Kasr- el-Nil barracks, Cairo, on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, 7th to 12th inst., at 7.30 p.m.
Burglary in Ramleh-boulevard.

Last night the office of Mr. Menahem Bracha, close to the, Messageries Maritimes agency, in the Ramleh boulevard, Alexandria, was burgled and the safe broken into. Eighteen Crédit Foncier (3% 1886) shares and a Lot Ture were stolen, besides £50 in cash. The ghaffir has been arrested on suspicion.
National Bank of Egypt.

The National Bank of Egypt announces that scrip certificates of the last issue of 50,000 shares may be exchanged for warrants to bearer on and after April 30. Scrip must be listed on forms to be obtained of the bank, 4 and 5, King William-street, E. C., and left three clear days for examination.
Evolution in Egypt

Logic always finishes by imposing itself, more or less naturally, in all countries, according to the degree of their intellectual development. The Berlitz Schools, for the teaching of the living languages, prosper on the same principle. The remarkable success obtained during the last few years by the branches of Alexandria (12 rue Rosette) and of Cairo (1 Sharia Kamel) is one of the best proofs of the constant evolution of Egypt in the right direction. [Advt.].
Florio-Rubattino Steamer Mystery.

The usual weekly Florio Rubattino steamer from Genoa, Leghorn, Naples, and Messina, was due to arrive at Alexandria yesterday, but the steamer has not been sighted yet and no news has been received as to the vessel’s whereabouts. The Alexandrian agency sent telegrams to Italy to the head office of the company this morning asking for news and a reply is expected this afternoon.

It is certain that the steamer touched at Naples and it is believed that as there was a general strike then at that port, the steamer has been delayed If so she is expected to arrive shortly for if she had been detained permanently at Naples the agency here would have received some notification on the subject by wire from Italy.

div.head: BOMB OUTRAGE IN MOSCOW.
GOVERNOR GENERAL WOUNDED.
div.p: Moscow. May 6.

A bomb was thrown at the Governor-General, Admiral Dubassoff, while he was returning from the cathedral to-day. He was wounded in the foot and his aide de-camp and a sentry were killed. His assailant, who wore officer’s uniform, is reported to have been killed.

div.head: THE DUMA.
CONSTITUTIONAL DEMOCRATS POLICY
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, May 5.

A congress of constitutional democrats has assembled here to consider their policy in the Duma. The programme advocated by the leaders includes universal suffrage, complete amnesty, and the abolition of capital punishment.
(Reuter)

Kokovtsoff as Minister of Finance.

div.head: THE SITUATION AT RAFAH.
div.p: The situation at Rafah, near El Arish, may be summed up as follows. -
The Turks are encamped at a point fifty yards on the Egyptian side of the frontier, some four miles from the coast. They number 50 soldiers, with 3 officers and a tax collector.

The two pillars which have always been recognised by the people of El Arish as the boundary marks were undoubtedly removed by the Turks on the night of April 12. Owing no doubt to the fact that the frontier is populated only by Bedouins who cultivate the plain between Sheikh Zeyoud—16 miles from El Arish—and Gaza in places where water is to be found the news seems to have taken some time to reach El Arish and Cairo.
Eleven Egyptian telegraph poles have been approriated and Turkish poles substituted.
The Sawarka Bedouins of the frontier district complain that the Turks have stolen their cattle and after driving them away have turned their horses loose on their corn fields.

A strip of land about 800 yards in width lying between the recognised frontier line and the road running from the interior to Ain Rafeib, north of Rafah, has been registered in the Saltan’s name. It is said to produce a good crop.

We gather that the attitude of the Turks towards the Egyptian delegates was courteous enough, but that they absolutely refused to admit the right of Capt. Waymouth, of H.M.S. Minerva, who accompanied them, to take any part whatever in the discussion relative to the violation of the frontier, on the ground that it was a purely Egyptian concern.

The so-called German mission, which arrived at El Arish and was sent back to Gaza, was composed of Hebrews, most of them Russian subjects, who wanted to buy land at El Arish. The fact that a German Jew led the party accounts for the extraordinary and misleading stories that have been spread as to the aims of the "mission.” In our opinion the “disguised German officers” or “secret agents” were simply what they declared themselves to be, viz., poor Jews looking for a good bargain in land. Henceforward the German agents must be classed with the great gun which one of our contemporaries averred — it is true on Bedouin evidence—to have entered Rafah behind a team of 18 horses.

Rafah is 25 miles E.N.E of El Arish and boasts a couple of good wells—Ain Rafeih and Ain Rafah. The boundary pillars, one of which bore an inscription commemorating H.H. the Khedive’s visit in 1897, have marked the frontier “min zamân,” and there seems no reason to distrust the evidence of the “oldest inhabitants” of El Arish in this particular.

div.head: THE MEDITERRANEAN FLEET.
div.p: It is stated that a number of cruisers belonging to the Mediterranean Fleet are off Alexandria, within reach of communication by wireless telegraphy.

div.head: H. M. S. MINERVA.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: Port Said, Sunday.

H.M.S. Minerva. returned here on Friday evening from Ei Arisb, after nearly a week’s absence. I have been unable to obtain any news of what took place there, but some very wild rumours are current Yesterday afternoon the Minerva received a wireless message from outside and left immediately, and up to the time of writing has not returned.
There is a rumour that the message received by the Minerva was to the effect that there was a ship in distress outside, but whether this is the case or not, I have been unable to ascertain.

div.head: ADMIRALTY TENDERS.
div.p: The Admiralty has invited tenders for the conveyance of some 650 men and 450 horses from Southampton or Queenstown to Alexandria for prompt embarkation.

div.head: ANOTHER TRANSPORT CHARTERED.
div.p: The Leyland liner Cestrian has been chartered by the Government to convey troops to Egypt. The Cestrian is at present homeward bound from Boston, and her arrival in the Mersey is expected in a few days.

div.head: GHAZI MUKHTAR PACHA INTERVIEWED.
THE TURKISH STANDPOINT.
div.p: In the course of an interview with a representative of the‘‘Egyptian Gazette" this morning, H. E.Ghazi Mukhtar Pacha,the Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, declared that the Sublime Porte agreed with Lord Fitzmaurice as regards the first part of his statement in the House of Lords on Wednesday, that “the Sinai peninsula did not form part of Egypt proper.” The Sublime Porte, however, could not agree with the second part of that statement, namely, that it remained under undisputed Egyptian Administration. Here the Porte differed, as Lord Fitzmaurice did not qualify that administration, which is, according to the Porte, temporary, and subject to reversion (reprenable) to Turkish administration.

The Ghazi further declared that in view of the commercial importance which would be likely to accrue to Akaba as the Red Sea terminus of the Hedjaz Railway, it would obviously not be advisable to have two different administrations so close to one another ; bat that Turkey had never entertained the least idea, which Great Britain attributed to her, of nearing the Suez Canal; all she desired was to have more elbow room for Akaba.
He was convinced of a pacific solution.
As for the report of Germany supporting Turkey, this was totally unfounded.

div.head: THE NATIVE ATTITUDE.
div.p: A correspondent writes: -

It is greatly to be hoped that the expression of opinion on the part of a native notable given to your Damanhour Correspondent, and which appeared in Saturday's paper, is anything but representative of the feelings entertained by the great majority of the Egyptian native population towards the English people. But should this unfortunately be the case, it is, I think, greatly due, not as you say in your leading article to “the tactless behaviour of two or three officers, private soldiers, or tourists,” but to the general want of consideration for native feelings shown by so large a number of English people. Europeans generally, I know, are quite as bad as my countrymen, but as they simply profit by British rule, without taking part in the government of the country; it is only the conduct of the English that stands so prominently in view. “We must show them our superiority,” said a young Englishman to me a few days ago, and it is this very claim of superiority that is so harmful in its effects, as well as unjust in its conception. Still it is greatly to be hoped that as a body the fellaheen, as you remark, are “either neutral or actually friendly to the British Occupation.” Indeed it would be strange were it otherwise, for it is inconceivable that after enjoying many years of freedom from tyranny, and experiencing an ever growing prosperity they would wish to go back to the old misrule—or worse. Why should they? Religions fanaticism, we are told would be the important factor, but there is certainly no reason why it should be. Even the suppression of slavery has been carried out in such a way that no interference with the Koran and its teachings has taken place, while the ill-advised action of certain missionary zealots has been promptly and effectually checked. A great responsibility rests at the present moment on the native Press. Certain papers have of late adopted a far more friendly attitude to the British Agent and Advisers, and the policy carried out by the Egyptian Government with their help has met with more cordial support than formerly. They will render valuable service if at the present crisis they do their best to strengthen the hands of the Egyptian Government. If they do this, and Egyptian officials take the same firm stand as they did in the recent Alexandria riot, when it will be remembered there was the same sense of fear of a Mohamedan rising, we can all await the action of diplomacy in the frontier question, or in the last resort the clash of arms, without contemplating the possibility of so terrible an event as a collision between the Mohamedan and Christian populations.

div.head: FRENCH OPINION.
div.p: M. Andre Mevil, writing in the “Echo de Paris,” says: “It is to be expected that England will embrace this opportunity of dealing a blow to Constantinople, showing the Porte that she is always to be counted with in the East. Indirectly, too, she would thus deal a blow to German influence.

“Nor must we forget that the dispute that has arisen concerning Egypt cannot leave ns indifferent, as, according to article 9 of the Convention of April 8, 1904, the French and British Governments are under engagements to lend each other mutual support of their diplomacy for the execution of the clauses relating to Egypt and Morocco. It is certain that if there be need England will receive from us the same support which she gave us in the Moroccan affair. From the International point of view, the. Tatah incident, then, may have serious consequences.”

div.head: THE ARMENIAN COMMUNITY.
AGITATION AGAINST BARTAU PACHA
IMPORTANT MEETING.
div.p: The agitation among the Armenian community of Alexandria on the subject of deposing Bartau Pacha from the presidency of the community came to a head yesterday, when a mass meeting of all the representatives of the community was held at the Alhambra Theatre. The female sex had been invited to attend, and a large number of ladies put in an appearance. Among those present were the leading notables among the Armenians in the city, with the exception of Bartau Pacha, who of course refrained from attending.

Mr. Bekarian was chosen chairman, and opened the proceedings with a short speech. He declared that it was a great democratic victory, and that the deposition of the president and of the old committee was due to the united efforts of the Armenians, assisted by the good services of Mustapha Pacha Ibadi, the new Governor of Alexandria, Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of the Alex andria City Police, and Heddaya Bey, who acted in a most fair and equitable manner in this question. The chairman then asked Mr. Damadian to give a concise explanation to the meeting of the reason why it had been convened.

Mr. Damadian, who spoke for three-quarters of an hour, declared that the community was entirely victorious and that Bartau Pacha had been obliged to resign against his will. He described the scenes which had occurred at the church on the last three Sundays, and the interview which the Armenian representative had had with the Governor of Alexandria. He then dealt with the destruction of the tablet erected by Bartan Pacha in the church and showed that it was broken with the general consent of the community, who objected to the presence of such a tablet in their church. He proposed that a new tablet should be erected in its stead bearing the date of the destruction of the former one, with the words “Maintain the Constitution.” This proposal was greeted with great cheers and during the entire speech Mr. Damadian was frequently applauded. He then read out an official letter received from the Bishop of Egypt, Monsignor Meguerditch Aghavnouni, addressed to the community, wherein he said that the preparations for the new elections would begin to-day (Monday). Mr. Damadian said that the action of the Bishop was very welcome but somewhat tardy.

During the speech a number of telegrams and letters were received from the Armenian communities at Cairo and Tantah, all strongly supporting the present policy of the colony. Mr. Damadian thanked the English advisers of the Khedivial Government for having given ear to their grievances, and ended a brilliant speech by calling on all his hearers to pull together so that the community should preserve a united front to its enemies.

Three representatives of the Armenians of Alexandria were afterwards elected by acclamation. These were Messrs. Shuorkian, Damadian, and Tonrohondjian. The meeting then closed, while the Armenian Band played the Khedivial March.

The agitation against Bartau Pacha began a month ago, when a lawsuit was brought against the Armenian newspaper “Azad Pen” for having given publicity to certain private actions of Bartau Pacha and Mr. Agop Onghourian. The newspaper was defended by Maitre Mercinier, who made a brilliant speech in defence. The speech was reproduced in the paper and its contents were such that an agitation was at once set on foot to depose Bartau Pacha.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: The King has been pleased to give and grant unto the under mentioned officers his Majesty’s Royal licence and authority to accept and wear decorations (as stated against their respective names) which have been conferred upon them by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered to his Highness:
IMPERIAL OTTOMAN ORDER OP THE MEDJIDIEH, SECOND CLASS.
Captain and Brevet Major (local Lieutenant-Colonel) George Bohun Macauley, C. M. G., Royal Engineers.
IMPERIAL OTTOMAN ORDER OF THE MEDJIDIEII, THIRD CLASS.
Captain William Elrington Longfield, Royal Engineers.
IMPERIAL OTTOMAN ORDER OF THE MEDJIDIEII, FOURTH CLASS.
Lieutenant Percy Calvert Lord, Royal Engieers.
IMPERIAL OTTOMAN ORDER OF THE OSMANIEH, FOURTH CLASS.
Lieutenant William Byron Drary, R. N. ; Captain Maurice Eden Sowerby, Royal Engi-neers ; and Lieutenant Stewart Francis Newcombe, Royal Engineers.

The King has been pleased to give and grant onto the Honourable Anthony Ashley Ivo Pelham, Charles Martin Hickley, Esq., and Arthur Russell Windham, Esq, of the Sudan Government Railways, his Majesty’s Royal licence and authority that they may respectively accept and wear the Insignia of the Fourth Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medjidieh, which decoration has been conferred upon them by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered to his Highness.

div.head: PORT SAID NOTES
WHAT PORT SAID OWES TO THE CANAL
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Port Said, Thursday.

In spite of many pessimistic prognostications, the colossal American floating dock, Admiral Dewey, got safely through the Canal, a fact which reflects great credit on the officials of the transit service of the Canal Co. It would be impossible to estimate how much Port Said owes to the company. In fact, the very existence and structure of the town and harbour are the result of the opening of the Canal.

The “foul and stagnant ditch,” founded on the earnings, according to Lord Palmerston, of "cafe waiters deceived by the newspapers lying on the tables, or grocers and dry goods assistants entrapped by the paper, in which they wrapped their wares," has proved to be a success beyond what the most sanguine may have dared to dream. In the words of Colonel Sir Howard Vincent, a town now flourishes with between 40,000 and 50,000 inhabitants, where fortunes have been made and will be made, where ships can coal quicker than anywhere else in the world; but which “The Daily News,” with that accuracy of forecast which has always distinguished it, ridiculed as absurd - “the building of a town without money, without water, without stone.” Synonymous as is the United States with everything typical of modern progress, she can as yet show nothing so illustrative of the grit necessary to put through, in spite of organized and influential opposition, so great a feat of engineering. When de Lesaeps cut the first sod of the Suez Canal, he had not at his disposal the mighty machines and appliances which America will use in her latest attempt to cut through the Isthmus of Panama. Long after his detractors are forgotten, the name of Lesseps will be honoured as that of a man who was able, not only to conceive a great idea, but to carry it out.
Russian Troops.

There seems to be no end to the almost constant stream of Russian troops being repatriated from Vladivostock to Odessa. One of their officers who came ashore will remember with gratitude one of the officials of the Passport Office, who, after the former left the office, found a pocket-book, fall of valuable papers and a large roll of banknotes, which was promptly returned through the Russian Consul.
An Innovation.

Many people will be pleased to hear that the police have reserved to themselves the privilege of granting leave to cafés to keep open all night At present the café must close at two in the morning ; consequently people living in their neighbourhood will no longer be disturbed from sunset to sunrise.
Street Pests.

It is pleasing to see also that the police are more vigilant in preventing the molestation of passengers by people selling obscene photographs and post cards, as well as keeping an eye on the numerous touts and shoe-blacks, whose name is legion. The supervision of the Rue de Commerce by two European police officials has done much to mitigate this nuisance.
The Dust Nuisance.

The provision of water-carts has considerably allayed the dust nuisance, though the roads are so far removed from what they ought to be that in places which have received an extra amount of water there is created a mud nuisance for a short time after their passing.
H.M.S. Minerva.
Yesterday evening the Minerva arrived from El-Areech, off the port. She sent ashore for letters and dispatches, and after the arrival of the Cairo train put out to sea again.
Personal.
The many friends of Mr. Mailing, British Vice Consul, will regret to hear that, owing to ill-health, it has been necessary for him to leave Port Said for a time for Europe.
We are pleased to hear that Dr. Orme, the cleaver surgeon at the Government Hospital, is making a good recovery in England.
Mr. Christian, the representative of Messrs. Wills & Co. in their contract work on the harbour extensions, has commenced his duties at Port Said.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
Suez, Saturday.
H. H. S. Nour el Babr sailed from Suez this afternoon for Akaba with despatches for H. M. S. Diana.
The Italian gunboat Barba Rigo arrived a few days ago at Suez from the Somali coast, and has been placed under the orders of the Italian Diplomatic Agency at Cairo.
Suez, Sunday.
H. M. S. Perseus arrived at Suez yesterday at 4 o’clock, and entered the Canal at 5.15 p.m. the same afternoon.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The M.M. steamer Sénégal, from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday, and is due at Alexandria to-morrow.
The Ellerman S. S. Algerian sailed hence on Saturday evening for Liverpool direct with a general cargo, including 772 bales of cotton and 13, 979 bags of onions.

div.head: SOCIETE KHEDIVIALE DE GEOGRAPHIE
div.p: La conférence de M. Salem Bey donnée samedi a beaucoup intéressé l’auditoire, parmi lequel figuraient plusieurs dames.

Laissant de oôté quelques opinions, que l’orateur s’est empressé de déclarer toutes personnelles, l’exposé détaillé de l’expansion sarrasine (africaine et non arabe) dans le midi et l’est de la France jusqu’à Metz, en Suisse, dans les Alpes Orientales et la vallée du Rhône, en Italie (Génois et Monferrato) et des traces laissées par cette expansion dans le souvenir, la langue et le sang même des indigènes, a été suivi pendant une heure et quart avec la plus vive attention.

M. Salem a fait remarquer que les contacts de l'Europe et de l’Afrique et les invasions réciproques, datent du commencement de l'histoire et que tandis que l’Europe n’a jamais pu tenir l’Asie, malgré Alexandre, Rome et les Croisades, l’Afrique a fini par devenir son terrain d’avenir. Mais pour que cet avenir, a-t-il conclu, soit durable, il faut que l’Europe abandonne une foule de préjugés sur les races africaines, il faut q’elle les étudie à fond dans leurs caractères ethniques et dans leur évolu¬tion historique.
Le conférencier a été très applaudi et la séance a été levée à 6 h.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie)
Bien que les affaires demeurent clairsemées, cependant quelques acheteurs commencent à se présenter. Ce matin même il y avait une petite demande qui laissait croire à une reprise.
Malheureusement ce bon début n’a pas eu de suite et les spéculateurs sont rentrés peu après dans leur apathie.

On croit généralement que cette indécision persistera jusqu'à ce que le conflit anglo-turc soit terminé. Le fait de l’ultimatum est donc en soi un évènement heureux pour la bourse puisqu’il réduit à 10 jours le délai de cette incertitude.
L’Agricole, l’Urbaine et le Comptoir ont repris.
Le cours de clôture de l’Agricole est 10 vendeurs, de l’Urbaine 6 1/16 et du Comptoir 7 5/16 l’ancienne et 6 1/8 la nouvelle.
La Delta Land, l’Investment et la Nile Land sont également soutenus.
Mais l’ensemble du marché, comme nous l’avons dit, est plutôt faible, avec tendance indécise.

Parmi les nombreuses sociétés en forma¬tion citons “The British Beer Breweries Limited,” constituée ces jours derniers à Londres et qui a pour objet la fabrication de la bière en (Egypte par des procédés spéciaux. On nous annonce que le Conseil d’administra¬tion est constitué partie en Egypte, partie en Angleterre et qu'il compte des noms connus comme ceux de Nungovich bey, Rostovitz bey, Gianaclis, Loukaïtis, G. M. Girdwood, A. W. Pearse, Henry Hinks, etc. etc.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, Samedi 5 Mai.

A Londres, hier, le Consolidé anglais a clôturé à 89 3/4, soit avec un 1/4 de baisse. L’Unifiés a, d’autre part, perdu une demi-livre à 104. La National Bank a regagné 1/8 à 26 1/2. L’Agricole est restée invariée à 10 1/8, de môme que la Daira à 17 1/2. La Delta Light a perdu 1/8 à 12 1/4.
A Paris, l’action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a regagné 1 franc à 772, et la Banque d’Athènes autant à 151.
Nous avons eu, ce matin, on marché calme, mais quelque peu plus actif et plus rassuré que ceux des jours précédents.
Le compartiment des Banques a été lourd. La National Bank et l’Agricole, délaissées, ont clôturé aux mêmes prix qu’hier. La Banque d’Orient a fléchi jusqu'à 136 pour remonter en clôture à 139.
Le Crédit Foncier est resté immobile à 777. La Daira s’est raffermie à 17 3/8.
La Nile Land a progressé à 16 3/8 1/2 ; la Wardan à 6 5/8-11/16.
Il y a eu un bon mouvement sur l’action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux qui a fait 4 7/16 pour clôturer à 4 3/8 ; la part de fonda¬teur est remontée à 85 pour finir à 80-82.
L’Union Foncière a baissé de 6 9/16 à 6 3/8-7/16.
Les Héliopolis ont été traités à 320. Les dividendes Tramways d’Alexandrie ont faibli a 340.
Les Omnibus du Caire ont été cotés 28 3/4-29.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont été offerts à 17 7/16. Las Baechler sont revenus à 4 25/33 pour clôturer à 4 13/16-7/8. Les Upper Egypt ont été échangés entre 4 15/32 et 4 17/32.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été ramenés à 4 3/16-1/4. Les Hooker sont restés entre £ 1 et 11 /32. On a fait courir en Bourse le brait que M. Williamson aurait effectivement donné sa démission de membre du conseil de la Delta Land par suite du dif¬férend relatif à la fusion avec l’Egyptian Land and General Trust. Il est prudent d’attendre la confirmation officielle de cette rameur.
Les Estates ont été plus faibles à 1 3/4-13/16; la part de fondateur est revenue à 11. Les Salt and Soda ont été plus fermes entre 22 sh. 9 et 23
Si nos informations sont exactes, une émis-sion intéressante, ou tout au moins rafraîchis-sante, se prépare au Caire, sons les auspices de la Banque de Saloniqne de notre ville.
Il s’agit de la British Beer Breweries of

Egypt Limited, au capital de £ 50,000, représenté par autant d’actions à £ 1 chacune, dont 15,000 seraient offertes à la souscription publique au pair,et le solde resterait à la souche pour les besoins éventuels de l’avenir.
L’objet de la nouvelle Société serait d’acquérir de la British Breweries of England Ltd. le droit exclusif d’exploiter en Egypte et au Soudan le brevet d’Hobson.

Cette invention, qui serait le résultat de plusieurs années de hautes recherches scienti-fiques, permettrait de fabriquer économique¬ment un “pale ale” et un “stout” qui conviendraient merveilleusement aux climats chauds, à Ceylan, par exemple, cù l’expérience a irait été déjà faite, et au Canada, bien que cette dernière contrée soit passablement dis¬tante de la zone tropicale.
Nos renseignements ne vont pas plus loin pour l’instant. Nous tâcherons de les compléter le plus vite possible afin de faire profiter nos amis de cette occasion unique.

En attendant, il faut oroire que, d’ici là, l’honorable établissement de crédit par l'intermédiaire duquel serait lancés l’entreprise recevra les données nécessaires sur le succès obtenu par les Sociétés similaires établies en des régions aussi diamétralement opposées que l’Amérique du Nord et les îles de l’Océan Indien.
Le poste devenu vacant dans le conseil d’ad-ministration du Crédit Foncier Egyptien par suite du décès de M. Félix Suares a été accepté par S.E. Boghos pacha Nubar.
L’émission des Grands Garages d’Egypte a été couverte deux fois et celle de la Cairo Suburban Building Lands Co. environ deux fois et demie.
Les lettres de répartition de cette der¬nière ont été expédiées hier soir aux destinataires.

A l’assemblée générale de la Société des Tramways d’Alexandrie, qui a été tenue avant-hier à Bruxelles, les propositions du conseil d'administration, que nous avons expo-sées dans notre Circulaire du 21 Avril dernier, ont été adoptées. Il a été décidé de payer un dividende da Frs. 6,25 par action privilégiée et de Frs. 2,75 par action de dividende.
Les quatre nouveaux administrateurs élus sont: MM. le baron Jacques de Menasce, Emin Karam, P. Glymenopoulo et le baron de Kuzel.
Carnet de l’actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de la Société Anonyme Agricole et Industrielle d’Egypte sont informés que les dividendes de l’exercice clôturé le 31 Janvier 1906 sont payables, au siège social au Caire, à partir du 13 Mai courant, à raison do Frs. 47,50 pour les actions de capital et Frs. 45 pour les parts de dividende, contre remise du coupon No. 9.

div.head: FIRST SUMMER MEETING.
div.p: The second day’s racing of the A.S.C. First Summer Meeting, which took place on Saturday under delightful weather conditions, was of the most successful description. There was a large attendance of race-goers and the greatest animation prevailed throughout the afternoon, the Pari Mutuel being largely patronised. The greatest interest was naturally taken in the big event of the season, the Grand Prize of Alexandria of L E. 1,000, which went to Abou Nadara. The win was a popular one, as this is Hussein Pacha Sionfi’s first racing season, and the rider, Fenwick, is to be congratulated on his victory. It was generally conceded that El Tahawi would win this race. There were some who thought that he had been kept in reserve the whole season for the purpose of winning this prize, but in the event he was not even placed. With such a big field, however, it might have been anybody’s race, and although the winner received a good deal of support at the betting enclosure, Tamerlan II., Suleik, Starboard Light, and Au Revior were held to have many points in their favour. The latter indeed looked like winning at one time, but the distance was too much for him. Another popular win was that of Hassan Pacha Mohsen’s with Karaguioz, in the National Stakes. And here we may say that everyone felt pleased to see the popular sportsman once again on the course, after his recent indisposition. It was a near thing for Karagioz, however, as he had not more than his nose in front of Hedieh. The latter mare of Khalil Pacha Khayat’s is one of the finest gallopers in the country and is worth watching. Karagioz is more of the type of the English horse. The Pony Plate, the second race on the card, afforded another close and exciting finish, Miassar just losing first place by a short head. This was a splendid race. Rainbow who was thought to have a good chance, only secured third place. The surprise of the day was the victory of Ajax II. in the Hadra Stakes, when the calculations of backers were entirely upset. For this race Aurelius, Brown Boy and Riado were the favourites, but in the event neither of these was placed, although Brown Boy would have stood a good chance had he not an fortunately broken a blood vessel. The Municipal Cup was a gift for Roi de l’Air, who, judging by his past form, was a "dead cert,” not withstanding the heavy weight he carried. The Pony Handicap went to the favourite, John Peel, while Eid surprised most people by coming in second. Backers had a good day, the returns being in most cases very satisfactory, The few lucky supporters of Ajax II. are to be congratulated on bringing off a 28 to 1 chance. As on the previous day, the band of the 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, under Bandmaster Fawcett, played a choice selection of music, which greatly enhanced the pleasure of the afternoon. There was a great rush for tea-tables, with the consequence that in many cases the service left a good deal to be desired. The following is a description of the various events —

NATIONAL STAKES of LE. 150; 2nd horse to receive L.E. 30 and 3rd horse LE. 20 out of tbe Stakes. For Maiden (at nomination) Arabs and Egyptian Country Breds Class II height for age and class with penalties. Distance round the course.
Hassan Pasha Mohsen’s chec.b. Karaguioz. 9.6. Koukides. 1
Khalil Pasha Khayat’s b.e.c.m. Hedieb, 7.8. Parsons. 2
Baron J. E. de Menasce’s br.e.c.b.m. Chance, 10.7. Matthews. 3
Hussein Pacha Sioufi’s ch.e.c.b.m. Aida, 7.8. Burnham. 0

The lot were despatched to a bsd start, Karaguioz being left at the post. He was not long however in making up lost ground, and soon came to the front with Aida in close company and Chance lying last. Coming into the straight Aida was done with and the race remained to Karaguioz and Hedieh, who ran an exciting race home, the former just winning by a short bead. Time : 2.30.
Totalisator paid P.T. 57 on winner and P.T. 32 and 46 for places.
PONY PLATE of P.T. 5,000, viz : P.T. 4,000 to winner, P.T. 700 to 2nd horse and P.T. 300 to 3rd horse. For Maiden at entry Arab ponies. Weight for age and inches with penalties. Distance 3/4 mile.
Khalil Pacha Khayat’s g.a.p. Suheil, 10.7. Jenkins. 1
Saleh Bey Yaghen’s g.a.p. Miassar, 9.9. Whiteside. 2

The field went off in a bunch, Rainbow showing the way. He and Beylan made most of the running till reaching the straight, when it was seen that all were riding. A splendid race home ended in Suheil winning from Miassar by a short head, Rainbow being halt a length behind, a good third, the rest close up. Time : 1.22 1/2.

Quick Returns had the best of an excellent start, but Brown Boy soon took up the lead and made the running, with Mokattam and Bonus at his heels. This order was maintained till out of the cutting, Ajax II. lying fourth. Half way up the straight Brown Boy was done with and Bonus took up the lead till reaching the public stand, when Ajax II. shot out and came with a clatter, winning in the easiest fashion from Mokattam by 3 lengths, 2 lengths separating second and third. Time : 2.20 1/3.
Totalisator paid P.T. 591 on winner and P.T. 122, 60, and 61 for places.

There was a somewhat straggling start. El Tahawi, An Revoir, and Tamerlan II. led to the mile post, Caprice and Mikado then forging their way to the front and making the rungning till the 3/4-mile post was reached. Here El Tahawi came to the fore again in company I with Nimrod and Boule de Neige. He was soon done with however and Boule de Neige, Abou Nadara and An Revoir entered the straight almost abreast. The latter looked all over a winner bat Abou Nadara made a hold I effort and won a fine race by half a length from Au Revoir. Nimrod was a oouple of lengths behind, third. Time: 2.46 1/2 (once round: 2.30).

The flag went down to a splendid start. Roi de l’Air jumped off at once and took op the lead, closely followed by Valentino and Moofid, the rest well up. After a false start, the tape having been broken, the field were sent off to a rather bad start. Shaiboub made the running followed by John Peel. The Bard, and Vino Tinto. At the 5-furlong post John Peel took up the running and led into the straight with Shaiboub, the pair being neck and neck together. div.head: LAWNN TENNIS
CAIRO v. ALEXANDRIA
div.p: This annual match took place on the 4th inst. on the K.S.C. coarts at Ghezireh. Doubles only were played. The teams were fairly representative though one or two of the best players were missing from both sides.
C. Cobbe and E. Guarino ( A.) beat Lewis and Campbell(C.) 6-3, 4-6, 7-5, beat Mackintosh and Hill (C.) 6-3, 6 -, beat Hughes and Barton (C.) 6-3,6-4.
W. Cumming and J. H. Percival (A.) beat Lewis and Campbell (C.) 6 4, 6-3, beat Mackintosh and Hill (C.) 6-3, 6-1, beat Hughes and Barton (C.) 6-3, 6-0.
O. J. Finney and O. Morice (A.) lost to Lewis, and Campbell (C.) 3-6, 4-6, lost to Mackintosh and Hill (C.)3-6, 4-6, beat Hughes and Barton (C.) 5-7, 6-2, 8-6.
Result : Alexandria won by 7 events to 2, 14 sets to 6.

div.head: BARON BAVASTRO DE CORTAZZI
div.p: The New York papers to hand are full of the doings of an alleged inhabitant of Alexandria, who rails himself Baron Bavastro de Cortozzi and declares that his father has large estates near Alexandria. The "New York Herald" of April 13 gives the following account of the case: - Baron Bavastro de Cortazzi, of Alexandria, Egypt, and Arlbett Sacky, sometimes known as "Count,” both of whom were intimately acquainted with Mrs. Blanche Turner Dennis, who died in suspicions circumstances on March 28 in the Hotel Marseille, 103rd street and Broadway, were separately interviewed by Coroner Shrady yesterday, and as a result a subpoena was served upon the Baron to appear to-day at an inquest into Mrs. Dennis’ death.

Baron de Cortazzi said Sacky, whom he met through—(we omit the name, which is a well-known one in Cairo), son of a high official in Egypt, introduced him to Mrs. Dennis as his fiancée in this city last September. In December Sacky and the woman went to a hotel in New London, Conn., and there, on Christmas Eve, de Cortazzi said, they had a violent quarrel, in which Sacky beat and kicked her. She and Sacky parted, but de Cortazzi was afterwards in frequent communication with her in the Hotel Marseille, and three days before her death, when he asked her if she supposed her illness was the result of the beating she had received from Sacky, she said she had not felt well since that time.

Sacky said he had met Mrs. Dennis early in September, through Harry Playle, a friend of himself and of her former husband, Major Hugh C. Dennis, of St. Louis. They had become engaged to be married, but after the quarrel in New London the engagement had been broken. He denied that it had been broken for reasons that he could not be forced to disclose.

"She suffered enough,” he added, "and now she is dead. After December 25 I did not have any communication with her, and I am not responsible for anything that occurred after that. A wealthy man in New York is implicated in the case. I know who he is, but I will not divulge his name.”
Sacky was to have been examined before Magistrate Wable yesterday on a charge of larceny preferred by Clare E. Pag, hot the hearing was adjourned until Saturday morning in the West Side Court.

div.head: THE ABYSSINIANS IN JERUSALEM.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Jerusalem, May 3.

The Governor of Jerusalem received a few days ago a telegram from the Emperor Menelik requesting him to call upon the Abyssinian clergy residing at Jerusalem, with the exception of those from the Tigre provinces, to meet together and to elect from amongst themselves a Superior in succession to Memhir Fakada, who has recently been recalled by the Emperor to Adis Abeba. Accordingly they assembled and unanimously elected Abba Yesus, and the Negus was informed of his nomination by Reshid Bey.

div.head: The Wardan Estate Company.
div.p: Issue of 10,000 Ordinary Shares of £5 each.
Making the total Issued Capital £150,000.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that by a Resolution passed by the Shareholders at the Annual General Meeting held on the 27th. March 1906 and confirmed at a subsequent Extraordinary General Meeting held on the 17th. April 1906, it was decided to issue 10,000 Ordinary Shares of £5 each at par plus 10/- being amount of Coupons Nos. 1 and 8 which will be attached to the Warrants so as to bring them to the same value as the Ordinary Shares already issued. The total amount per Share will therefore be £5 : 10/- payable as follows :—
1st. Payment of £1 on Application
2nd. Payment of £1 : 10/- on Allotment the balance to be paid as and when required by the Directors who will give three months’ notice of any Call made by publication in the Newspapers.
No notice of any Call will be given before the 30th. September 1906.

Interest at the rate of 7 % per annum will be charged on all overdue Instalments and the Shares will be liable to forfeiture if the Instalments are not paid as they fall due as per Article 8 of the Statutes.
Applications will be received by the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo and Alexandria, during business hours on the 9th. and 10th. of May 1906.
Every person holder of Ordinary Shares has the right to an allotment of one Share of the present Issue for every two Ordinary Shares held by him at the time of Issue.
All Shareholders who wish to exercise their right of preference must deposit before the 9th. of May 1906 their Shares Warrants with any of the following Banks in Cairo or Alexandria :—

The National Bank of Egypt, The Anglo Egyptian Bank Ltd. Bank of Egypt Ltd., Crédit Lyonnais, Imperial Ottoman Bank and Bank of Athens, and send to THE NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT, in Cairo or Alexandria before 5 p.m. of the 10th. day of May 1906 their Application with the Bankers’ Certificate printed thereon duly completed, together with the amount due on Application.
Application Forms can be obtained at any of the above mentioned Banks.
For The Wardan Estate Company F. H. RUSSELL, Secretary.

Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
